meanings.definition: To fill with love or admiration
meanings.sent1: She felt enamored by the beautiful sunset.
meanings.sent2: The puppy's playful antics enamored everyone in the room.
meanings.sent3: His magic tricks never failed to enamor the audience.
meanings.sent4: The melody of the song enamored her like a spell.
meanings.sent5: The artist's painting had the power to enamor all who gazed upon it.

meanings.sent1: The storyteller's words had the ability to enamor the children.
meanings.sent2: The mysterious stranger seemed to enamor everyone at the party.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous kitten tried to enamor its way into getting more treats.
meanings.sent4: The old bookshop had a certain charm that could enamor any book lover.
meanings.sent5: The dance performance was so captivating that it could enamor even the toughest critic.

meanings.sent1: He was deeply enamored with the idea of traveling the world.
meanings.sent2: She found herself enamored with the new romantic comedy movie.
meanings.sent3: The young couple's constant bickering only made them more enamored with each other.
meanings.sent4: The poet's words made her feel as if she was enamored with the universe.
meanings.sent5: The scent of fresh flowers in the garden made him feel enamored with nature.
